Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Experimental miniaturization of guppy offspring
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine which of two possible causes, difficulty in feeding or constraints on development, are responsible for setting the lower limit for the size of fish. The findings will help test theories of life-history evolution, and provide developmental and functional insights into limitations on recruitment in marine fisheries. The size of individuals spans many orders of magnitude, but is constrained at the large and small extremes by principles of physics. As organisms become smaller, the world surrounding them becomes more resistive to their movements, which are thought to limit the size of fish offspring to no smaller than 4.5 mm. At this size, fish larvae experience difficulty feeding. Alternatively, size at birth is also related to the time it takes to reach maturity. This project will test these alternatives using guppies as a model system. The project incorporates undergraduate mentoring and research training. Additionally, the project will utilize the guppy as a model for the teaching of evolution and ecology within local high school classrooms.

This project involves two miniaturization manipulations: hydrodynamic and developmental. In the first manipulation, the researchers will increase the viscosity of water using dextran, thereby effectively miniaturizing the offspring in size, but not development. In the second manipulation, the researchers will remove yolk from the eggs of developing embryos, thereby miniaturizing and prematurely delivering the young. Because guppies are live bearing, the yolk manipulation requires culturing guppy embryos in vitro in order to access the yolk sac. With a pulled capillary tube, yolk will be removed such that guppy embryos will be forced to feed exogenously at approximately 4.4 mm. Feeding rates will be compared between the hydrodynamic and developmental manipulations to determine if size or maturity is the limiting feature when feeding on suspended food items. Feeding trials will be filmed using high-speed video to measure jaw kinematics and determine the Reynolds number under which the feeding apparatus is operating during suction feeding.

Institution.Name: Brown University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BROWN UNIVERSITY IN PROVIDENCE IN THE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND AND PROVIDENCE PLANTATIONS

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have completed the work described in DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Experimental miniaturization of guppy offspring, which included two field trips to the country of Trinidad and Tobago, training and collaborating with an undergraduate research fellow, presenting the findings at several scientific conferences and publishing two open access, peer-reviewed, scientific journal articles.

 

As an evolutionary biologist, I am interested in understanding why parents vary the investment of energy into their offspring, and what effect this has on the health and fitness of the offspring. To test this question, I used the Trinidadian guppy (a live-bearing fish), which vary among populations in the size of baby fish that the females produce. The experiment consisted of obtaining live guppy offspring from various populations and filming their feeding performance (using high-speed video) under control and experimental treatments. The water was treated with an inert sugar that increases the viscosity (stickiness) of water, while not affecting any of the physiology of the fish. By increasing the viscosity of the water, we are able to make it more difficult for the fish to suction feed, which emulates what it feels like to be very small. By doing this manipulation over a range of offspring sizes, we are able to understand how size and maturity influence feeding performance.

 

To execute the work, we hired an undergraduate research assistant. We trained this research assistant to rear the offspring, manipulate the viscosity, collect and then analyze the data.

 

The goals of the experimental manipulation were accomplished, though the findings were unanticipated. The viscosity manipulation made it more difficult for the tiny fish to feed, but interestingly, the increased water viscosity did not affect feeding performance to the dramatic degree that was expected.

 

Instead, what we found was that all guppies capable of feeding in the heightened viscosity environment did so with the same success that they have when feeding in normal water. The increased viscosity made it more difficult to produce suction, but feeding success was not hindered, and this success was most closely associated with the age of the offspring (age since fertilization). This finding suggested that feeding performance among guppy offspring was not as much a product of the environment as the degree to which they are developed out of the egg.

 

It is perhaps not surprising that larger, more mature fish are capable of feeding with greater success and suction performance. But what is surprising is that the experimental manipulations did not influence the degree of feeding performance that these offspring exhibited. We learned that the environment is not as great of a factor affecting feeding performance as is the underlying degree to which these organisms have developed.  

 

The Broader Impacts goals were met through presentation of the work at three scientific conferences and publication in two open access, peer-reviewed journal articles.

 


Last Modified: 05/04/2018
Modified by: Terry R Dial
